title-group.article-title: Cadmium concentrations in shrimp (Penaeus semisulcatus and Penaeus monodon) caught from the coastal areas in southern Iran

article-meta.aff: 1Young Researchers Club, Shahrekord Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrekord, Iran
2Department of Food Hygiene, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Shahrekord Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrekord, Iran
3Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Shahrekord Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrekord, Iran

author-notes.corresp: E Rahimi, Department of Food Hygiene, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Shahrekord Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrekord, Iran. Email: rahimi@iaushk.ac.ir

abstract.p: This study was undertaken to determine the concentration of cadmium in two shrimp species, namely, Penaeus semisulcatus and Penaeus monodon caught from the coastal areas in southern Iran. Cadmium concentration was determined by graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrophotometry in 91 shrimp samples after nitric acid/perchloric acid digestion. Accuracy of the analysis was checked by various methods including the use of reference material. The mean ± SD of cadmium concentrations in shrimp samples were 0.128 ± 0.144 (μg/g). The cadmium concentrations ranged from 0.010 to 0.96 μg/g of the muscle tissues of shrimp. Higher cadmium concentration in shrimp samples was found in summer (significant p < 0.05). The results show that the mean concentration of cadmium in shrimp is lower than the maximum allowed levels according to International standards, although the concentration of cadmium in only one sample was more than the amount recommended by Food and Agriculture Organization. Therefore, no risk to the consumer arises from the cadmium contents of the shrimp caught in these areas.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Shrimp are an important seafood species throughout the world. They are generally consumed fresh and known to be high in protein and low in fat (Erkan et al., 2007). Foodstuff of marine origin, principally seafood, is the food with the highest concentration of zinc, iodine, and selenium. Heavy metals including mercury, cadmium, lead, and arsenic are frequently found as environmental contaminants and are known because of their toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic effects (Belitz et al., 2001). Heavy metals enter costal waters from various sources. Rock and soils directly exposed to surface water are usually the largest natural source. Another major source is anthropogenic input, such as that from fossil fuel combustion, mining, smelting, and solid waste incineration (Stein et al., 1996).

Problems associated with metal contamination were first highlighted in industrially advanced countries because of their larger industrial discharges and because of incidents of mercury and cadmium toxicity in Japan and Sweden. Minamata disease in Japan caused the death of many people due to the intake of fish contaminated with toxic levels of mercury. Similarly, the devastating effects of cadmium on animals were amply demonstrated by itai-itai disease in humans. Several studies have revealed that cadmium is also dangerous to aquatic organisms and can be bioaccumulated in food chains (Rainbow, 1995; Soegianto et al., 1999; Soegianto and Hamami, 2007).

Crustaceans have been used successfully as biological indicators of coastal pollution and in the assessment of the influence of heavy metals on the marine environment. Marine crustaceans, including shrimp and crab, can be employed as bioindicators to assess the marine environment, since they can accumulate heavy metals and other pollutants (Darmono and Denton 1990; Kress et al., 1998; Mantelatto et al., 1999). Hence, information on the heavy metal concentration in their tissues is potentially useful in considering toxicological and public health. Shrimp and crab show potential as a metal biosentinel because they are relatively sedentary, abundant, and are commonly found in both nonpolluted and polluted environments. Shrimp and crabs have been well established as bionindicators for monitoring the concentration of heavy metals in many areas of the world (Darmono and Denton, 1990; Hosseinkhezri and Tashkhourian, 2011; Kargin et al., 2001; Kress et al., 1998; Mantelatto et al., 1999; Palmer and Presley, 1993; Rahimi et al., 2010; Raissy et al. 2011; Vazquez et al., 2001).
This study was undertaken to determine the concentration of cadmium of two shrimp species, namely, Penaeus semisulcatus and Penaeus monodon caught from the coastal areas in southern Iran.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: A total number of 91 shrimp samples, including P. semisulcatus (n = 34) and P. monodon (n = 57), caught from the costal areas in southern Iran were obtained from local commercial dealers in Isfahan and Khuzestan province of Iran during winter 2009 and spring to fall 2010. All samples were packed in plastic bags and transported to the laboratory. Samples were frozen at −18°C until analysis.

sec.title: Reagents and apparatus
sec.p: All reagents were of analytical reagent grade unless otherwise stated. Double distilled water was used for the preparation of solutions. The stock solutions of metals (1000 mg/L) were obtained by dissolving appropriate salts of the corresponding metals (E. Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). All the plastic and glass ware were soaked in nitric acid for 15 min and rinsed with deionized water before use.

sec.title: Digestion and determination of cadmium
sec.p: The moisture content of the tissue samples was determined according to the Association of Official Agricultural Chemists (AOAC) method in triplicate (WHO, 2000). The samples were digested using the wet digestion techniques (Oze et al., 2006) and then cadmium was determined against aqueous standards.

Cadmium concentrations were determined by graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Perkin Elmer, 4100), employing paralytic platform graphite tubes (Perkin Elmer, AS-40), ascorbic acid, and palladium for matrix modification. The limit of detection in the acid digest was set at three times the SD of the mean blank value, which was 0.096 ppb.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data were transferred to Microsoft Excel spreadsheet (Microsoft Corp., Redmond, WA, USA) for analysis. SPSS 16.0 statistical software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) was used for the analysis of variance and Student’s t test analysis; differences were considered significant at values of p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Table 1 shows the results of cadmium concentration in the muscle tissue of shrimp samples. Cadmium is a nonessential element in foods and natural waters, and it accumulates principally in the kidneys and liver (Belitz et al., 2001). Its toxic effects have been highlighted by some cases of collective poisoning in people who consumed a large amount of fish (Chou et al., 2002; Renzoni et al., 1998). It is generally accepted that seafood represents one of the major sources of cadmium in the human food chain.

caption.p: Median and range of cadmium concentrations (μg/g) in muscle tissue of Penaeus monodon and Penaeus semisulcatus from the Persian Gulf.

sec.p: It is well known that the crab and shrimp can concentrate heavy metal in their tissues (Chou et al., 2002; Mantelatto et al., 1999; Pourang et al., 2005; Sivadason and Nambisan, 1988; Turkmen et al., 2006; Vazquez et al., 2001). An average cadmium load of 0.139 μg/g (median 0.088 μg/g) was found in the samples. The median cadmium concentrations found in the muscular tissue of shrimp samples are the near values reported by various surveys conducted in different countries (Marx and Brunner, 1998; Mokhtar et al., 2009; Ozden, 2010; Soegianto and Hamami, 2007). However, it appears to be lesser than that of some published studies (Firat et al., 2008; Kargin et al., 2001). The results of the present study show that the cadmium concentration in shrimp samples caught from the coastal areas in southern Iran is generally lower than the maximum acceptable concentration value of 0.5 μg/g, according to Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization (FAO/WHO, 2001).

In the current study, apparent pattern in the seasonality of cadmium concentration was observed in the shrimp samples (Table 2). These results are comparable with those reported by other investigators. The lowest and highest cadmium content in shrimp samples were found in spring and autumn (p < 0.05), respectively.

caption.p: Median and range of cadmium concentration (μg/g) in muscle of shrimp collected for four seasons in the Persian Gulf.

sec.p: According to Sokolowski et al. (2004), Cogun et al. (2005), and Wu et al. (2007), metal concentration have been shown to vary seasonally in some aquatic invertebrate species. Variation in metal concentration among the samples could have been dependent on factors such as size categories, ecological niche, trophic levels, or metabolic requirements. For example, bottom-dwelling and demersal species are known to have higher concentrations than more pelagic species, possibly due to greater exposure to contaminated sediments (Parsons, 1999).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results show that the mean concentration of cadmium in shrimp is lower than maximum allowed levels according to International standards, although the concentration of cadmium in only one sample was more than the amount recommended by FAO. Therefore, no risk to the consumer arises from the cadmium contents of the shrimp caught in these areas.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
